montenegro.title: Montenegro
montenegro.promoText: In winter, I have a special love for Montenegro. During this time of year, the sea becomes as smooth as glass, and the air is crystal clear and fresh. Walking along the shore is pure delight, with the crisp breeze filling your lungs and the sight of pristine white yachts captivating your gaze. It’s equally enchanting to wander aimlessly through the city streets, admiring the ancient stonework of the buildings and the vibrant splashes of ripe lemons and mandarins.

1.text:
Herceg Novi is an ancient and very charming town whose attractions can be explored in one or two days. The central square, the clock tower, and the Orthodox Church of St. Michael the Archangel. There are also two fortresses - the Sea Fortress (Forte Mare) and the Kanli Kula Fortress.


However, the best part of the city for me is the promenade. Walking along the sea never gets old; the water in the Adriatic is an amazing color. Every day brings a new view. Today, the water is mirror-like, and a diver with an orange signal buoy is gathering sea delicacies; tomorrow, waves after a storm are splashing over the pedestrian paths while seabirds search for food.

photos.2: The central square with the clock tower
photos.3: Orthodox Church of St. Michael the Archangel

2.text: The promenade, over 5 kilometers long, was built on the site of an old railway. At one end of the promenade is the Lazure Hotel complex and its marina, where you can admire yachts or arrange a sea trip; at the other end is the most modern and bustling area, Igalo. Along the promenade, there are numerous cafes and restaurants where you can try local cuisine, have some sushi rolls, or grab a slice of pizza to take with you on your walk.

photos.1: The tunnel left over from the old railway

3.text:
In Herceg Novi, we stayed in a charming studio on the third line. There was a lemon tree in the yard, and the owner of the house allowed us to pick one lemon per day. It’s so nice to drink tea with a lemon that you didn’t buy but picked with your own hands.


It was also quite unusual that all stores are closed on Sundays, so arriving on a Sunday means 'starvation' – but there is a solution: cafes/restaurants and gas stations are open. Everything is also very specialized: bread and pastries are sold in bakeries, meat in butcher shops, and fruits in fruit stores.
